==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
−
Meta-ethics is the branch of ethics that seeks to understand the nature of ethical properties, and ethical statements, attitudes, and judgments. Meta-ethics as a discipline gained attention with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903 in which Moore first addressed what he referred to as ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore's rebuttal of naturalistic ethics, his [[Open Question Argument]] sparked an interest within the analytic branch of western philosophy to concern oneself with second order questions about ethics; specifically the [[semantics]], [[epistemology]], and [[ontology]] of ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hume]] had outlined a sceptical view with his [[Is-ought problem|emphasis on the difference between facts and values]].
+
Meta-ethics is the branch of ethics that seeks to understand the nature of ethical properties, and ethical statements, attitudes, and judgments. Meta-ethics as a discipline gained attention with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903 in which Moore first addressed what he referred to as ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore's rebuttal of naturalistic ethics, his [[Open Question Argument]] rekindled an interest within the analytic branch of western philosophy concerning second order questions about ethics; specifically the [[semantics]], [[epistemology]], and [[ontology]] of ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hume]] had outlined a sceptical view with his emphasis on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
     
The epistemology and semantics of ethics divides into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[Non-cognitivism (ethics)|non-cognitivism]]; a distinction that is often perceived as equivalent to that between [[Descriptivism|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that ethical judgements are nether true nor false, that there are not facts in virtue of which we can accept them or reject them<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref>. Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that ethics is essentially concerned with judgments of the same kind as knowledge judgments; namely, about matters of fact.
 
The epistemology and semantics of ethics divides into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[Non-cognitivism (ethics)|non-cognitivism]]; a distinction that is often perceived as equivalent to that between [[Descriptivism|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that ethical judgements are nether true nor false, that there are not facts in virtue of which we can accept them or reject them<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref>. Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that ethics is essentially concerned with judgments of the same kind as knowledge judgments; namely, about matters of fact.
    −
The ontology of ethics is concerned with the idea of value-bearing things or properties, i.e. the kind of things or stuff that correspond to or are referred to by ethical propositions. Non-descriptivists and non-cognitivists believe that ethics dos not require a specific ontology, since ethical propositions do not refer to objects in the same way as descriptive propositions. This is known as an anti-realist position. Realists on the other hand must explain what kind of entities, properties or states are relevant for ethics, and why they have the normative status characteristic of ethics.
+
The ontology of ethics is concerned with the idea of value-bearing things or properties, i.e. the kind of things or stuff referred to by ethical propositions. Non-descriptivists and non-cognitivists believe that ethics does not require a specific ontology, since ethical propositions do not refer. This is known as an anti-realist position. Realists on the other hand must explain what kind of entities, properties or states are relevant for ethics, how they have value, and why they have the normative status characteristic of ethics.
